thread.title: Tory David Davis 'leans in to kiss' Diane Abbott in Commons bar, so she tells him to 'f**k off'

title: Tory David Davis 'leans in to kiss' Diane Abbott in Commons bar, so she tells him to 'f**k off'

persons.name: jeremy corbyn diane abbott theresa may david davis brexit

organizations.name: politics labour party conservative party bbc european union house

text:
Tory David Davis 'leans in to kiss' Diane Abbott in Commons bar, so she tells him to 'f**k off' The Brexit Secretary was seen by journalists leaning in for a kiss after the Article 50 vote, but the Shadow Home Secretary recoiled. Share Comments By Mikey Smith 10:27, 9 FEB 2017 News Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union David Davis (Photo: Getty Images Europe) politics Brexit secretary David Davis tried to kiss Diane Abbott in a House of Commons bar last night, so she told him to “f**k off”.
The incident reportedly occurred in Strangers’ Bar, a popular watering hole for MPs in the House of Commons.
Mr Davis was seen by journalists leaning in for a kiss after the Article 50 vote, but the Shadow Home Secretary recoiled.
He reportedly “walked off laughing”.
Diane Abbott (Photo: Daily Mirror) The exchange happened after Ms Abbott voted in favour of the Tory Brexit Bill in its final Commons reading last night, despite having campaigned for Remain ahead of the Referendum.
One journalist who witnessed the event said it was "unclear" whether the exchange was friendly banter or "had a real edge", according to the Telegraph
In a statement following the vote, Ms Abbott insisted she still believes Britain is better off in the EU.
Brexit Secretary David Davis (Photo: PA) She said: “I campaigned for remain and still believe that it is not in our best interests to leave the European Union. However to say that because the vote went the wrong way we are going to ignore the votes of millions of people up and down the country, would be a blow to democracy.
“This does not mean that we have to accept Brexit in the haphazard way in which it is being handed to us. I like many are rightfully concerned about Theresa May’s Brexit. A Brexit in accordance to Tory values.
“I was in Parliament for the Maastricht Treaty, which was just a revision to the EU Treaty. We debated it for forty-two days. MPs have been given just five days to debate coming out of the EU all together. This demonstrates how arrogant Theresa May is, how much she does not want to involve Parliament, and how much she wants to bulldoze things through.”
She accepted the passage of the Article 50 bill had been “a challenge” for Labour, but said she voted for the bill as “a loyal supporter of Jeremy Corbyn and a loyal member of the Shadow Cabinet.”
The Mirror Party at Circo, in Albert Dock Liverpool, to mark the annual Labour conference 2016. Pictured here at the Mirror annual party is Clive Lewis MP, the Shadow Defence Secretary, who is believed to have 'punched' a wall in fury after Jeremy Corbyn's aides changed a pro-Trident renewal speech on the auto queue, while he was delivering it (Photo: Daily Mirror) Her cabinet colleague, Clive Lewis, resigned from his position as Shadow Business Secretary last night, in order to vote against the bill.
He joined 51 of his Labour colleagues to vote against the Government while 13 did not vote.
Conservatives seized on Labour's turmoil over the vote to back the start of Britain's divorce talks with the European Union to claim the Opposition was "hopelessly divided".
Asked about the rebellion by Labour MPs, Mr Corbyn told the BBC: "No, it's not a disaster."
